questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of daytime sleepiness and a dry mouth. She says her sleepiness is due to getting up to urinate several times each night. During this time, she has also had increased thirst. She currently drinks up to 20 cups of water daily. She does not feel a sudden urge prior to urinating and has not had dysuria. She has a history of multiple urinary tract infections and head trauma following a suicide attempt 3 months ago. She has bipolar I disorder and hypertension. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Examination shows poor skin turgor. Mucous membranes are dry. Expiratory wheezes are heard over both lung fields. There is no suprapubic tenderness. She describes her mood as “good” and her affect is appropriate. Neurologic examination shows tremor in both hands. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 151 mEq/L and an elevated antidiuretic hormone concentration. Urine osmolality is 124 mOsm/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Hypothalamic injury can result in central DI with low ADH levels. However, this patient's elevated ADH levels suggests nephrogenic DI.

B) INCORRECT:

Paraneoplastic syndrome has a wide array of clinical manifestations. Elevated ADH levels due to exogenous secretion in patients with paraneoplastic syndrome results in syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) which, unlike the condition in this patient, manifests as excessive free water retention, euvolemic hyponatremia, and high urine osmolality. The elevated ADH levels in this patient are, therefore, more likely due to another cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Pituitary tumors and subsequent hypothalamic injury can result in central DI with low ADH levels. However, this patient's elevated ADH levels suggests nephrogenic DI.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with psychogenic polydipsia (PP) present with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality levels. However, PP causes suppressed release of ADH, low serum Na+, and low serum osmolality levels due to the dilutional effect of excessive water intake. Furthermore, patients with PP do not have dehydration like this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperaldosteronism can be asymptomatic or manifest with symptoms of hypokalemia such as headache, muscle weakness, and polyuria. Secondary hypertension, low or normal serum K+, and metabolic alkalosis may also be seen. In nephrogenic DI, which this patient has, the volume contraction resulting from excessive water loss results in increased activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), causing secondary hyperaldosteronism.

F) CORRECT:

Nephrogenic DI is the most common complication of long-term use of lithium, the first-line mood stabilizer for patients with bipolar disorder, as is the case here. Lithium is believed to cause nephrogenic DI by interfering with ADH signaling in the collecting duct cells, which results in reduced expression of water channel aquaporin-2 (AQP2) in these cells and subsequently an elevated ADH in an attempt to compensate.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).
questions.hint: This patient has signs of diabetes insipidus (DI): polyuria, polydipsia, nocturia, dehydration, increased serum Na+, and decreased urine osmolality.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increased urinary frequency over the past month. She also reports having dry mouth and feeling thirsty all the time despite drinking several liters of water per day. She has not had any weight changes and her appetite is normal. She has a history of obsessive-compulsive disorder treated with citalopram. She drinks one to two beers per day. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Na+

130 mEq/L


Glucose
100 mg/dL


Osmolality
265 mOsmol/kg H2O


Urine



Osmolality
230 mOsmol/kg H2O


The patient is asked to stop drinking water for 3 hours. Following water restriction, urine osmolality is measured every hour, whereas serum osmolality is measured every 2 hours. Repeated laboratory measurements show a serum osmolality of 280 mOsmol/kg H2O and a urine osmolality of 850 mOsmol/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebral salt wasting syndrome, which may occur in patients after neurosurgical procedures, is a poorly understood cause of hypovolemic, hypotonic hyponatremia. Patients with cerebral salt wasting syndrome may have low serum osmolality and (paradoxical) polyuria. However, this patient lacks other important features of cerebral salt wasting such as hypovolemia (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia) and a history of intracranial pathology.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has some typical features of central diabetes insipidus (DI), including polyuria and polydipsia. However, individuals with DI typically present with mild hypernatremia, high-normal serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. In patients with DI, the water deprivation test typically results in rising serum osmolality > 300 mOsmol/kg, while urine osmolality remains relatively unchanged. Moreover, in the absence of nocturia, DI is very unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH), which manifests with hyponatremia and decreased serum osmolality, can be caused by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as citalopram. In patients with SIADH, increased activity of the antidiuretic hormone (ADH) decreases free water clearance, which results in low serum osmolality, as seen here, but urine osmolality is usually inappropriately high. Moreover, patients with SIADH do not present with polyuria or polydipsia, and serum osmolality does not reach normal values during water restriction.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has some typical features of diabetes mellitus (DM), including polyuria and polydipsia. However, her serum glucose is normal and she is missing other important findings of DM such as fatigue, polyphagia, and weight changes. Moreover, patients with DM would not present with low serum osmolality reaching normal values during water restriction.

E) INCORRECT:

Although hyponatremia is a typical finding in patients with beer potomania, this patient only drinks one to two beers per day, which is not enough to cause this condition.

F) CORRECT:

This patient has a history of excessive thirst and water intake (polydipsia), polyuria, and hyponatremia, all of which are findings consistent with primary polydipsia (PP, also known as psychogenic polydipsia). The water deprivation test allows PP to be differentiated from diabetes insipidus. Normal values of serum and urine osmolality after the water deprivation test indicate that both the release and effect of ADH are intact, ruling out diabetes insipidus and confirming the diagnosis of PP.

In patients with PP, an excess in free water intake lowers serum osmolality and causes a compensatory reduction in the secretion of ADH, which will dilute urine to a maximum (reducing urine osmolality) to excrete excess fluid.

See “Primary polydipsia vs. central DI vs. nephrogenic DI” table.
Image Description:

AVP: arginine vasopressin
BMP: basic metabolic panel
DI: diabetes insipidus
Na+: sodium
POsm: plasma osmolality
UOsm: urine osmolality

G) INCORRECT:

This patient has some typical features of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI), including polyuria and polydipsia. However, individuals with DI typically present with mild hypernatremia, high-normal serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. In patients with DI, the water deprivation test typically results in rising serum osmolality > 300 mOsmol/kg, while urine osmolality remains relatively unchanged. Moreover, in the absence of nocturia, DI is very unlikely.
questions.hint: After the water deprivation test, the patient's serum and urine osmolality are normal. These findings are suggestive of a condition that is commonly associated with psychiatric diseases such as obsessive-compulsive disorder.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man comes to the physician because of frequent urination for the past 2 months. He has been urinating 10–12 times during the day and 3–4 times during the night. He says he is drinking a lot of water to compensate for any dehydration. He is concerned he may have diabetes mellitus like his parents. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.3 g/dL


Serum



 Na+

149 mEq/L


 K+

3.9 mEq/L


 Cl-

102 mEq/L


 Glucose
90 mg/dL


 Osmolality
306 mOsmol/kg H2O


Urine



 Osmolality
210 mOsmol/kg H2O


A water deprivation test is conducted. After 2 hours of fluid restriction, his plasma osmolality is 315 mOsmol/kg H2O and his urine osmolality is 210 mOsmol/kg H2O. One hour after an ADH analog injection, his plasma osmolality is 276 mOsmol/kg H2O and his urine osmolality is 425 mOsmol/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline can be used to treat syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). This drug inhibits the action of ADH, which causes a decreased concentration of the urine. This patient's laboratory results show high serum osmolarity, which rules out SIADH. Increased ADH secretion leads to increased water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules and the collecting ducts of the kidneys, resulting in low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality.

B) CORRECT:

Desmopressin, an ADH analog, is the most appropriate treatment for patients with central DI, which is caused by deficient ADH secretion. Combined with his laboratory results, this patient's polyuria, polydipsia, and nocturia indicate DI. The diagnosis is confirmed by his failure to concentrate urine after the water deprivation test, and successful concentration of urine after an ADH analog trial.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is used to treat nephrogenic DI. In nephrogenic DI, dysfunction of the ADH receptors in the distal tubule and collecting ducts prevents ADH from exerting its normal function. Hydrochlorothiazide increases the concentration of electrolytes in the renal medulla, which in turn leads to increased water reabsorption into the renal interstitium by osmosis. From here, water can move back into the blood, leading to increased concentration of the urine, which treats DI. This patient's response to the ADH analog rules out nephrogenic DI.

D) INCORRECT:

Tolvaptan, which is used in hyponatremic states such as syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), causes selective water excretion in the urine by antagonizing ADH on the vasopressin 2 receptor. This patient is already excreting excess water in the urine, as his inability to concentrate the urine prior to receiving the ADH analog demonstrates.

E) INCORRECT:

Amiloride is used to treat nephrogenic DI by blocking sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule and collecting ducts, which leads to more concentrated urine. This patient's response to the ADH analog rules out nephrogenic DI. A different drug is, therefore, more suitable.

F) INCORRECT:

Fluid restriction was already performed in this patient for diagnostic purposes. An inability to concentrate the urine after the water deprivation test confirms DI. Moreover, after administration of the ADH analog, urine osmolarity increased, indicating an ADH deficiency. Fluid restriction would not correct the problem in this patient who lacks ADH, the hormone responsible for the compensatory response to fluid deprivation. Fluid restriction is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with SIADH.
questions.hint: This patient has mild hypernatremia, low urine osmolality, and high plasma osmolality. Administration of an ADH analog increases urine osmolality and causes plasma osmolality to normalize. This combination of findings is highly suggestive of central diabetes insipidus (DI).

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of agitation, confusion, and lethargy. She has also had progressive recurring headaches and visual impairment over the last month. Three days ago, she had a seizure but has not seen a physician. She is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Capillary refill time is more than 3 seconds. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

148 mEq/L


 Cl-

100 mEq/L


 K+

3.8 mEq/L


 HCO3-

26 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/L


 Glucose
90 mg/L


 Creatinine
0.8 mg/L


 Osmolality
300 mOsmol/kg H2O


Urine osmolality
240 mOsm/kg H2O


Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's hypernatremia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While increased water intake, as seen in patients with psychogenic polydipsia, can cause decreased urine osmolality, it would also result in hyponatremia and decreased serum osmolality.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased ADH release can be of pituitary (e.g., trauma, drugs) or ectopic origin (e.g., small cell lung cancer), resulting in a syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion. Increased ADH activity causes more water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, which results in hyponatremia, decreased serum osmolality, and increased urine osmolality, unlike this patient with hypernatremia, increased serum osmolality, and decreased urine osmolality.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased ADH receptor activity is seen in nephrogenic DI, which manifests similarly to this patient's condition. However, a history of progressive headache, visual impairment, and recent seizure suggests a brain tumor affecting the pituitary gland as a likely cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased ACTH secretion is seen in patients with Cushing disease (CD). While patients with CD can present with hypernatremia and metabolic alkalosis due to the mineralocorticoid effect of cortisol, this patient's normal glucose and potassium are more suggestive of an alternative diagnosis (CD causes hyperglycemia and hypokalemia). Moreover, classic symptoms such as hyperpigmentation, buffalo hump, abdominal striae, hirsutism, acne, hyperglycemia, and hypertension would be expected.

E) CORRECT:

An underlying neurological disorder (e.g., a brain tumor such as craniopharyngioma or metastasis) can lead to direct or indirect dysfunction of the hypothalamic neurons of the posterior pituitary gland, which causes decreased ADH secretion and consequently, central DI. Central DI may be idiopathic or secondary; other secondary causes include traumatic brain injury, pituitary bleeding, subarachnoid hemorrhage, pituitary ischemia, meningitis, and neurosurgery.

DI is confirmed via the water deprivation test, which would show no change in urine osmolality despite a rising plasma osmolality. After DI is confirmed, desmopressin is administered to distinguish between central or nephrogenic DI. A subsequent increase in urine osmolality after a desmopressin trial indicates intact ADH receptors in the kidneys, confirming central diabetes insipidus.

See “Primary polydipsia vs. central DI vs. nephrogenic DI” table.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased ACTH secretion due to an impaired hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis (secondary adrenal insufficiency) can be a complication of an underlying neurological disorder. However, decreased ACTH secretion typically manifests with hyponatremia (due to lack of cortisol and its mineralocorticoid effect), and the urine concentrating capacity is not affected. Additionally, weight loss, weakness, nausea/vomiting, hyperkalemia, hypoglycemia, and hypotension would be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's features of dehydration (agitation, confusion, lethargy, prolonged capillary refill time) and hypernatremia with a low urine osmolality indicate severe diabetes insipidus (DI). Additionally, her recurring headaches, visual impairment, and recent seizure raise suspicion of a brain tumor.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and excessive thirst. During this period, she has not been able to sleep through the night because of the frequent urge to urinate. She also urinates more than usual during the day. She drinks 4–5 liters of water and 1–2 beers daily. She has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, hypertension treated with lisinopril, and bipolar disorder. Therapy with valproic acid was begun after a manic episode 3 months ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Irregular flank masses are palpated bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Na+

152 mEq/L


K+

4.1 mEq/L


Cl−

100 mEq/L


HCO3−

25 mEq/L


Creatinine
1.8 mg/dL


Osmolality
312 mOsmol/kg H2O


Glucose
98 mg/dL


Urine osmolality
190 mOsmol/kg H2O


The urine osmolality does not change after 3 hours despite no fluid intake or after administration of desmopressin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin is a first-line medication used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM). This patient's polydipsia, polyuria, and fatigue are similar to what might be seen in a patient being newly diagnosed with DM. However, her normal blood glucose, hypernatremia, and response to the initial tests point to nephrogenic DI, which is not treated with metformin.

B) INCORRECT:

Water restriction is a technique used to treat psychogenic polydipsia (PP). Patients with PP typically have mild hyponatremia and low serum osmolarity. This patient has already had a 3-hour water restriction without any change in her urine osmolarity, making another management option more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels. This medication is used for the treatment of lithium-induced nephrogenic DI. However, this patient is taking valproic acid as a mood stabilizer, which does not lead to nephrogenic DI. In some other cases of nephrogenic DI, potassium-sparing diuretics may be considered but only in addition to first-line therapy and not as a monotherapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Chlorpropamide is a sulfonylurea commonly used to treat central DI because of its additional effect of increasing antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion and strengthening the effect of ADH on the kidney. This medication would have no effect on this patient's nephrogenic DI and could cause dangerous hypoglycemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid should be discontinued in patients experiencing side effects. However, valproic acid is more likely to cause side effects such as hepatotoxicity. This medication is well tolerated by the kidney and does not cause DI. Discontinuing valproic acid will not resolve this patient's symptoms.

Lithium, another mood-stabilizing medication, can cause nephrogenic DI.

F) INCORRECT:

Small amounts of 3% saline can increase sodium levels in patients with severe hyponatremia caused by beer potomania. However, this patient has hypernatremia and her history does not suggest beer potomania.

G) CORRECT:

In addition to a low-salt and low-protein diet, hydrochlorothiazide treats nephrogenic DI by paradoxically reducing the volume of urine produced. Hydrochlorothiazide leads to increased sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubules. As a result, less water reaches the ADH-sensitive distal tubules and urine volume decreases.

H) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is an effective treatment for central DI. However, this patient has the nephrogenic form of the disease which does not respond to desmopressin. Moreover, this patient has already been administered desmopressin with no improvement.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of renal disease presents with polyuria, nocturia, polydipsia, mild hypernatremia, a high serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. In combination with the absent response to fluid restriction and desmopressin administration, these features suggest nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI).

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of increased urinary frequency, bone aches, nausea, and fatigue. She says she has felt increasingly thirsty despite drinking 5–6 liters of water daily and has been waking up frequently during the night to urinate. The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, major depressive disorder, and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril, escitalopram, and metformin. She drinks one beer each night. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.3 g/dL


Serum



 Na+

151 mEq/L


 K+

3.9 mEq/L


 Cl-

102 mEq/L


 Ca2+

13 mg/dL


 Urea nitrogen
8 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


 Glucose
101 mg/dL


 Osmolality
306 mOsmol/kg H2O


 Parathyroid hormone
130 pg/mL


Urine



 Osmolality
255 mOsmol/kg H2O


Following a water deprivation test, plasma osmolality is 309 mOsmol/kg H2O and urine osmolality is 256 mOsmol/kg H2O. One hour after desmopressin administration, plasma osmolality is 305 mOsmol/kg H2O and urine osmolality is 259 mOsmol/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's increased urinary frequency?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A history of polydipsia, polyuria, and nocturia in combination with increased plasma osmolality and decreased urine osmolality after a water deprivation test is suggestive of diabetes insipidus (DI). This patient's lack of response to desmopressin (i.e., plasma osmolality remained high and urine osmolality remained low) indicates nephrogenic DI. Although the pathomechanism by which hypercalcemia causes nephrogenic DI is not entirely understood, changes in interstitial osmotic gradient, hypercalcemic tubulointerstitial injury, and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels are thought to be involved. Correction of hypercalcemia usually reverses these changes. Medications such as lithium and demeclocycline can also cause this condition.

See “Primary polydipsia vs. central DI vs. nephrogenic DI” table.
Image Description:

AVP: arginine vasopressin
BMP: basic metabolic panel
DI: diabetes insipidus
Na+: sodium
POsm: plasma osmolality
UOsm: urine osmolality

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) manifests with polyuria, polydipsia, nausea, signs of dehydration (e.g. dry mucous membranes), and increased plasma osmolality in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, plasma osmolality in HHS is usually > 320 mOsmol/kg due to a blood glucose level typically ≥ 600 mg/dL.

C) INCORRECT:

Beer potomania is typically caused by an excessive intake of beer and a low dietary solute intake. This patient only drinks one beer per day, which is not enough to cause this condition. Moreover, in contrast with this patient's findings, beer potomania manifests with dilutional hyponatremia and low serum osmolality, and urine osmolality is typically below 100 mOsm/kg.

D) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic polydipsia (PP) manifests with polyuria and polydipsia. However, because of the dilutional effect of excessive water intake, patients with PP typically present with hyponatremia and low serum osmolality. Moreover, both the ADH secretion and the renal ADH receptors are intact in patients with PP, so plasma and urine osmolality values would be expected to be normal after a water deprivation test.

E) INCORRECT:

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) manifests with polyuria, nocturia, polydipsia, hypernatremia, and increased plasma osmolality, and decreased urine osmolality after a water deprivation test. However, urine osmolality increases after desmopressin administration in patients with central DI because renal ADH receptors are intact.

F) INCORRECT:

Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) can be induced by medications such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (e.g., escitalopram), which this patient takes. However, in contrast with this patient's findings, SIADH manifests with increased urine osmolality, decreased plasma osmolality, and hyponatremia due to increased water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts.
questions.hint: Hypercalcemia and elevated parathyroid hormone levels suggest primary hyperparathyroidism. Hypercalcemia is a common cause of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency room because of confusion. His wife says he has been urinating more frequently than usual for the past 3 days. He has not had fever or dysuria. He has bipolar disorder, for which he takes lithium. His pulse is 105/min, and respirations are 14/min. He is lethargic and oriented only to person. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and increased capillary refill time. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 158 mEq/L and an antidiuretic hormone (ADH) concentration of 8 pg/mL (N = 1–5). Which of the following is the most likely site of dysfunction in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection, ischemia, and injury of the posterior pituitary gland can result in ADH deficiency, which is the underlying cause of central diabetes insipidus. Although this patient has signs of diabetes insipidus, he has an increased serum ADH concentration, which is more consistent with a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection, inflammation, and malignancy of the hypothalamus can impair ADH synthesis in the supraoptic nucleus, resulting in ADH deficiency and subsequent central diabetes insipidus. Although this patient has signs of diabetes insipidus, he has an increased serum ADH concentration, which is more consistent with a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

C) INCORRECT:

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is caused by an impaired response to ADH in the kidneys. Although the main function of the descending loop of Henle is to concentrate the urine, its cells do not express ADH receptors and are thus not the site of dysfunction that causes nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

D) CORRECT:

Lithium interferes with ADH signaling in principal cells of the collecting duct, thus reducing the expression of aquaporins and impairing the kidney's ability to concentrate urine. This effect results in renal free water loss, which manifests as frequent urination of hypotonic urine, hypernatremia, and dehydration. Reduced extracellular fluid volume and increased serum osmolarity stimulate ADH secretion, which results in an increased serum ADH concentration.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

E) INCORRECT:

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is caused by an impaired response to ADH in the kidneys. The juxtaglomerular apparatus is involved in the regulation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. However, it is not involved in the production or secretion of ADH or response of the kidneys to this hormone.
questions.hint: Polyuria and elevated ADH levels are consistent with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, an adverse effect of lithium therapy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of excessive bleeding after undergoing a dental procedure. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 195,000/mm3, a partial thromboplastin time of 44 sec, and a prothrombin time of 12 sec. A one-stage clotting assay shows a decreased factor VIII. Therapy with a drug that acts on endothelial cells is initiated. This drug is most likely to result in which of the following?

choices.text: Decreased cAMP in renal tubular cells
Increased tubular fluid osmolarity in the loop of Henle
Decreased binding of angiotensin II to AT1 receptor
Increased permeability to urea in the collecting duct

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased cAMP in renal tubular cells would be observed in patients who were given vasopressin (receptor) antagonists, e.g., conivaptan. Desmopressin, however, increases cAMP via interaction with V2-receptors and subsequent activation of adenylyl cyclase. The effects of high cAMP concentrations include the integration of aquaporins into the plasma membrane of collecting duct cells and an increase in water reabsorption.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased tubular fluid osmolarity in the loop of Henle would be seen in patients who have received mannitol, which is freely filtered by the kidneys without undergoing reabsorption and thereby creates a strong osmotic gradient with subsequent diuresis. Mannitol is commonly used in patients with elevated intracranial pressure or acute prerenal failure. In contrast, the concentrating effect of desmopressin occurs only in the collecting ducts, thus leaving the osmolarity in the loop of Henle.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased binding of angiotensin II to AT1 receptors would be observed in a patient taking angiotensin receptor blockers, not desmopressin. ARBs would be of no use in this patient, as they promote diuresis through vasodilation and natriuresis and have no role in the treatment of hemophilia.

D) CORRECT:

Increased permeability to urea in the collecting duct is found in patients who are treated with vasopressin analogs. This group of drugs binds to V2-receptors, triggering a cascade of intracellular reactions that ultimately result in increased numbers of UT-A1 proteins in the apical plasma membrane. UT-A1 facilitates urea reabsorption in the inner medullary collecting duct.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased bleeding time would not be seen in this patient who is receiving desmopressin, which shortens aPTT and bleeding time. These blood parameter changes are mediated by a release of factor VIII and vWF through cAMP-mediated cell-signaling.
questions.hint: This boy's excessive bleeding after a dental procedure and an increased aPTT raise suspicion for hemophilia A, which is very likely considering his deficient factor VIII levels. Desmopressin, a synthetic analog of vasopressin, is the medical treatment of choice for mild hemophilia.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with bipolar I disorder and hypertension comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of increased thirst, urinary frequency, and sleep disturbance. He says that he now drinks up to 30 cups of water daily. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Examination shows decreased skin turgor. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 149 mEq/L, a potassium concentration of 4.1 mEq/L, and an elevated antidiuretic hormone concentration. His urine osmolality is 121 mOsm/kg H2O. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic polydipsia (PP) can occur during an acute bipolar psychosis and would present with polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality levels, all of which this patient has. However, water intoxication from PP would cause hyponatremia and low serum osmolality levels, due to the dilutional effects, and subsequently low ADH levels. Furthermore, patients with PP would not have features of dehydration (e.g., decreased skin turgor).

B) CORRECT:

Increased serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in a patient with features of diabetes insipidus is suggestive of a nephrogenic cause. Nephrogenic DI is the most common complication of long-term use of lithium, the first-line mood stabilizer for patients with bipolar disorder. Lithium is believed to cause nephrogenic DI by interfering with ADH signaling in the collecting duct cells, which results in reduced expression of water channel aquaporin-2 in these cells.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

C) INCORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is synthesized in the hypothalamus and then transported to the posterior pituitary gland for secretion. Destruction of the posterior pituitary gland or the hypothalamic stalk by a large pituitary tumor can result in features of diabetes insipidus. However, this would lead to decreased ADH levels, indicating central diabetes insipidus, rather than increased ADH levels, suggesting nephrogenic DI, as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for both small cell lung cancer (SCLC) and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung. SCLC can cause high ADH levels due to SIADH, but patients with SIADH would have hyponatremia and a high urine osmolality. Polydipsia, polyuria, hypernatremia, and a low urine osmolality would not be expected. SCCs of the lung can secrete PTHrP, which can, in turn, result in hypercalcemia with subsequent neuropsychiatric disturbances and nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, the neuropsychiatric disturbance would usually be acute or subacute, unlike this patient's chronic psychiatric disorder. Moreover, this patient does not have a cough or a history of weight loss that would suggest a pulmonary malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

A tumor in the adrenal cortex can cause primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome), which may lead to hypertension and, occasionally, mild hypernatremia (145–150 mEq/L). However, on its own, primary hyperaldosteronism would not cause polyuria, polydipsia, or features of dehydration such as decreased skin turgor. Hypokalemia caused by primary hyperaldosteronism can desensitize the renal tubules to ADH and, consequently, lead to mild nephrogenic DI, which this patient has. However, this patient's potassium levels are normal.
questions.hint: This patient has features of diabetes insipidus (DI): polyuria, polydipsia, dehydration, hypernatremia, and decreased urine osmolality (< 300 mOsmol/kg).

questions.text:
A 58-year old man comes to his physician because of a 1-month history of increased thirst and nocturia. He is drinking a lot of water to compensate for any dehydration. His brother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 151 mEq/L and a fasting glucose concentration of 95 mg/dL. A water deprivation test shows:

Urine osmolality(mOsmol/kg H2O)


Initial presentation
295
285


After 3 hours without fluids
305
310


After administration of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) analog
280

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH) causes hyponatremia and free water retention as a result of excess ADH levels. This patient has hypernatremia, polyuria, and polydipsia, none of which are findings of SIADH.

B) INCORRECT:

Nephrogenic DI is a subtype of DI in which circulating ADH is present but the kidneys are unable to respond appropriately. In a patient with nephrogenic DI, urine osmolality will remain unchanged or only mildly increased following desmopressin administration, and serum osmolality will remain elevated. This patient's serum osmolality normalized following desmopressin challenge, while his urine osmolality increased, indicating the kidneys are responsive to ADH.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's polydipsia, polyuria, and inability to concentrate urine after a water deprivation test are diagnostic of diabetes insipidus (DI). His responsiveness to an ADH analog (e.g., desmopressin), which is indicated by the significantly increased urine osmolality, rules out nephrogenic DI. This patient has central DI, which is caused by defects in the synthesis or secretion of ADH, e.g., those caused by brain tumors (craniopharyngioma), neurosurgery, traumatic brain injury, pituitary ischemia (Sheehan syndrome), or infection (meningitis).

BMP: basic metabolic panel
DI: diabetes insipidus
Na+: sodium
POsm: plasma osmolality
UOsm: urine osmolality

D) INCORRECT:

Primary polydipsia manifests with intake of unusual amounts of water and polyuria, as seen here. However, primary polydipsia typically presents with hyponatremia and low urine osmolality, and it is associated with psychiatric diseases including schizophrenia and obsessive-compulsive disorder (psychogenic polydipsia). At baseline, this patient was hypernatremic, had a normal to mildly elevated plasma osmolality, and had normal urine osmolality, which rules out primary polydipsia as a cause of his excess thirst and polyuria.

E) INCORRECT:

Osmotic diuresis refers to the diuretic effect of glucosuria in drawing free water from the renal interstitium into the nephron lumen. This phenomenon contributes to the polyuria and polydipsia observed in patients with diabetes mellitus. Although this patient has a family history of diabetes mellitus, his fasting glucose was within normal range. The results of his water deprivation test and desmopressin challenge suggest a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: The patient would likely benefit from treatment with desmopressin.

questions.text: Two days after undergoing transsphenoidal removal of a pituitary macroadenoma, a 35-year-old woman reports increased thirst and frequent urination. The surgery was uncomplicated. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Her serum sodium concentration is 153 mEq/L and fasting serum glucose concentration is 92 mg/dL. Which of the following findings in the nephron best describes the tubular osmolality, compared with serum, in this patient?

choices.text: Distal ascending loop of Henle is hypertonic
Distal descending loop of Henle is hypotonic

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sodium, potassium, and chloride are reabsorbed in the distal ascending loop of Henle, which is impermeable to water and hypotonic (∼100 mOsm/L) compared to the serum. The ascending loop of Henle is impermeable to water regardless of ADH concentrations. Therefore, this part of the nephron would remain physiologically hypotonic, not hypertonic, even in the setting of central DI.

B) INCORRECT:

Osmotic movement of water in the descending loop of Henle is driven by the hyperosmolality of the interstitial space of the renal medulla. The fluid in the distal part of the descending loop of Henle is, therefore, hypertonic (600-1200 mOsm/L) compared to the serum. This hypertonicity is not affected by ADH, as there are no V2 receptors located here.

C) INCORRECT:

In the proximal convoluted tubule, water and solutes (e.g., electrolytes) are reabsorbed in equal amounts. The osmolality of the tubular fluid in the PCT is dependent on serum osmolality, rather than ADH levels. The PCT would, therefore, remain isotonic (∼300 mOsm/L) rather than hypertonic when compared to the serum.

D) CORRECT:

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused by a lack of ADH, which impairs the reabsorption of free water from the collecting ducts (and the late distal convoluted tubules). ADH normally stimulates V2 receptors to increase the expression of aquaporins. The inability to reabsorb free water (e.g., inability to concentrate the urine) results in hypotonic urine, polyuria, and dehydration, which in turn triggers thirst and polydipsia, as seen in this patient. Urine osmolality is typically low (< 500 mOsmol/kg) and serum osmolality is high (> 299 mOsmol/kg) in patients with DI.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

E) INCORRECT:

Water and sodium chloride are reabsorbed in the distal convoluted tubule, which has V2 receptors that are stimulated by ADH. However, a lack of ADH would decrease the permeability to water and thereby decrease the osmolality in this part of the nephron, making the fluid in the distal convoluted tubule hypotonic, not hypertonic.
questions.hint: Polyuria, polydipsia, and mild hypernatremia should raise suspicion for inadequate ADH. The history of recent neurosurgery suggests central diabetes insipidus caused by damage to the hypothalamus or hypothalamic tract.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of increased urination. She has also had dry mouth and excessive thirst despite drinking several gallons of water daily. She has a history of obsessive-compulsive disorder treated with citalopram. She drinks 1–2 cans of beer daily. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a Na+ concentration of 130 mEq/L, a fasting glucose concentration of 138 mg/dL, and an osmolality of 265 mOsmol/kg. Urine osmolality is 230 mOsmol/kg. The patient is asked to stop drinking water for 3 hours. Following water restriction, repeated laboratory studies show a serum osmolality of 280 mOsmol/kg and a urine osmolality of 850 mOsmol/kg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has some typical features of central diabetes insipidus (DI), including polyuria and polydipsia. However, individuals with DI typically present with mild hypernatremia, high-normal serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. In patients with DI, the water deprivation test typically results in rising serum osmolality > 300 mOsmol/kg, while urine osmolality remains relatively unchanged.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary hyperparathyroidism (pHPT) is most often asymptomatic but can manifest with polyuria and polydipsia, which are seen in this patient, as a result of hypercalcemia-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. However, individuals with pHPT present with mild hypernatremia, high-normal serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has some typical features of syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH), including hyponatremia and decreased serum osmolality, and SIADH can be caused by SSRIs such as citalopram. In patients with SIADH, increased activity of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) decreases free water clearance, which results in low serum osmolality, but urine osmolality is usually inappropriately high. Moreover, unlike this patient's findings, SIADH does not cause polyuria, polydipsia, or serum osmolality correction after water restriction.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has some typical features of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI), including polyuria and polydipsia. However, individuals with DI typically present with mild hypernatremia, high-normal serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. In patients with DI, the water deprivation test typically results in rising serum osmolality > 300 mOsmol/kg, while urine osmolality remains relatively unchanged.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with a history of excessive thirst, polydipsia, polyuria, hyponatremia, and dilute urine, findings that are all consistent with primary polydipsia (psychogenic polydipsia). The water deprivation test allows primary polydipsia to be differentiated from diabetes insipidus. Normal serum and urine osmolality values after the water deprivation test indicate that both the release and effect of ADH are intact, ruling out diabetes insipidus and confirming the diagnosis of primary polydipsia.

In patients with primary polydipsia, excessive free water intake lowers serum osmolality and causes a compensatory reduction in ADH secretion, which will dilute urine to a maximum (reducing urine osmolality) to excrete excess fluid.
Image Description:

AVP: arginine vasopressin
BMP: basic metabolic panel
DI: diabetes insipidus
Na+: sodium
POsm: plasma osmolality
UOsm: urine osmolality

F) INCORRECT:

Although hyponatremia is a typical finding in patients with beer potomania, this patient only drinks 1–2 cans of beer per day, which is not enough to cause this condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) manifests with polyuria and polydipsia, which are seen in this patient. However, patients with HHS usually present with profound dehydration and significant hyperglycemia (serum glucose > 600 mg/dL, which are unlikely in a patient with a normal physical examination and vitals. Moreover, HHS would result in high rather than low serum osmolality.
questions.hint: This patient has polyuria, polydipsia, and both low serum and urine osmolality levels that correct with water deprivation. This medical condition is commonly associated with psychiatric diseases such as obsessive-compulsive disorder.

questions.text: A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of irritability and poor feeding that began 2 days ago. He was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and his birth weight was 3280 g (7 lb 4 oz). His 8-year-old sister and his father are healthy. During both pregnancies, his mother had severe polyuria. Today, he weighs 2900 g (6 lb 6 oz). Physical examination shows dry skin and mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and a sunken anterior fontanelle. During the examination, he cries without tears. Laboratory studies show a serum osmolality of 305 mOsmol/kg H2O and a urine osmolality of 45 mOsmol/kg H2O. After the administration of a vasopressin analog, urine osmolality remains decreased. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this newborn's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A high-protein diet is contraindicated in patients with DI because it increases renal urea excretion, which causes solute diuresis and worsens polyuria. Rather, protein restriction (< 1 g/day) is often advised for patients with DI.

B) INCORRECT:

Excessive sodium intake (e.g., a high-sodium diet) is contraindicated in patients with DI because it causes natriuresis and worsens polyuria (i.e., solute diuresis). Rather, sodium restriction (≤ 100 mEq/day) is often advised for patients with DI.

C) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline acts as a vasopressin (ADH) antagonist that induces nephrogenic DI, worsens diuresis, and is, therefore, contraindicated in this patient with DI. Instead, demeclocycline can be used to treat syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion, a disorder that, contrary to this patient's presentation, manifests with decreased serum osmolality (due to free water retention) and increased urine osmolality.

D) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin, a vasopressin (ADH) analog, is used to treat central DI, which can manifest with weight loss, features of dehydration, and decreased urine osmolality. However, in central DI, urine osmolality would increase following the administration of a vasopressin analog. Instead, this patient has nephrogenic DI (renal resistance to vasopressin), as evidenced by the failed desmopressin trial (i.e., failure of urine osmolality to increase following the administration of desmopressin). Desmopressin has, therefore, already been proven ineffective.

E) CORRECT:

Indomethacin is used to treat nephrogenic DI because of its ability to inhibit renal prostaglandin synthesis, which promotes the action of ADH on the collecting ducts, resulting in decreased diuresis. This male newborn has hereditary nephrogenic DI, most commonly caused by an X-linked mutation in the vasopressin V2 receptor gene (AVPR2), which results in the failure of principal cells to respond to vasopressin (ADH). Females with a heterozygous mutation are typically asymptomatic because of the presence of a functional gene and lyonization of the mutated gene. However, they may develop polyuria during pregnancy, as seen in this neonate's mother, because of increased clearance of vasopressin by placental vasopressinase. In contrast, males with the mutation present with severe symptoms soon after birth.

Other therapeutic measures to treat nephrogenic DI are adequate hydration, dietary salt and protein restriction (to prevent solute diuresis), and hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) therapy. Although HCTZ is a diuretic, in patients with nephrogenic DI it paradoxically decreases urine volume by an incompletely understood mechanism.
questions.hint: Features of severe dehydration (e.g., weight loss > 9%, irritability, poor feeding, dry skin and mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, sunken anterior fontanelle, increased serum osmolality) and very low urine osmolality that does not correct with the administration of a vasopressin analog indicate nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI).

He has a history of celiac disease and follows a gluten-free and vegetarian diet. His brother has type 1 diabetes mellitus. His medications include occasional ibuprofen for headaches. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 81 kg (179 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's current symptoms?

choices.text: Decreased pituitary secretion of antidiuretic hormone
Impaired renal response to antidiuretic hormone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased pituitary secretion of the antidiuretic hormone (central diabetes insipidus) causes polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality. However, diabetes insipidus results in hypernatremia and increased serum osmolality (due to free water loss) rather than hyponatremia and low serum osmolality.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

B) INCORRECT:

Osmotic diuresis occurs in conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS). These conditions can manifest with polyuria, polydipsia, nausea, vomiting, headache, and light-headedness. Furthermore, both DKA and HHS are complications of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM), which is a possible diagnosis in this patient given the personal history of celiac disease, an autoimmune condition associated with T1DM, and the family history of T1DM. However, in both DKA and HHS, serum osmolality and urine osmolality are increased rather than decreased.

C) INCORRECT:

An impaired renal response to antidiuretic hormone (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus) causes polyuria, polydipsia, and low urine osmolality. However, diabetes insipidus results in hypernatremia and increased serum osmolality (due to free water loss) rather than hyponatremia and low serum osmolality.

D) INCORRECT:

A very low dietary solute intake severely limits free water excretion and predisposes patients to developing hypotonic hyponatremia, even with normal levels of water intake. This condition, referred to as beer potomania syndrome, typically occurs in individuals with chronic alcohol use but can also occur in individuals with dietary restrictions. However, patients with this condition are typically malnourished; this patient's BMI of 25 kg/m2 makes this condition unlikely. Moreover, polyuria and polydipsia are not reported as presenting symptoms, and low urine osmolality is usually not seen at initial presentation; polyuria and low urine osmolality typically occur only once solute intake is restored (results in brisk diuresis).

E) CORRECT:

The combination of low serum osmolality and low urine osmolality indicates that vasopressin secretion is appropriately suppressed and the kidney's ability to dilute urine is intact. These findings also indicate that the primary cause of decreased serum osmolality is extravascular compartment dilution due to excessive water intake, which occurs in patients with primary polydipsia (PP, psychogenic polydipsia). This condition typically occurs in patients with psychiatric illnesses. Although the pathogenesis of this condition is not entirely understood, a central dysfunction of thirst regulation is thought to play an important role. On rare occasions, PP can also occur as a result of hypothalamic lesions that alter the thirst center's osmoregulatory setpoint (e.g., in neurosarcoidosis, multiple sclerosis). The serum osmolality and sodium concentrations of patients with this condition rapidly return to normal when limiting the water intake, as excess water is excreted by the kidney.

See “Primary polydipsia vs. central DI vs. nephrogenic DI” table.

POsm: plasma osmolality
UOsm: urine osmolality
questions.hint: This patient has hypotonic hyponatremia and nonspecific symptoms of sodium imbalance (e.g., nausea, vomiting, headache). Had he undergone a water deprivation test, his urine osmolality would have risen to normal levels.

A 46-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital 2 days ago after she fell off a ladder and sustained a head injury. She also sustained mild contusions to the forehead, right shoulder, right arm, and right leg. She was found to have a small frontal subdural hematoma and was admitted to the hospital for observation. She has been slightly lethargic and confused since admission, and these symptoms have progressively worsened despite stable findings on repeat head CT imaging. She has had some mild headache but no dizziness or visual changes. She is passing large amounts of light yellow urine.
On physical examination, she has a blood pressure of 102/70 mm Hg, a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. She appears lethargic and is oriented to self and place but not time. Her oropharynx is clear, but her mucous membranes are dry. Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Both cerebral salt wasting and the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion cause hyponatremia; however, neither would manifest with hypernatremia and inappropriately low urine osmolality.

B) CORRECT:

Hypernatremia accompanied by low urine osmolality and elevated serum osmolality is characteristic of central diabetes insipidus, which can be a complication of head trauma.

The low urine osmolality is the key to diagnosis; it indicates that the level of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is inadequate to maintain normal fluid balance. Normally, the posterior pituitary gland releases ADH in response to a reduction in the plasma volume and an increase in the plasma osmolality. ADH increases the permeability of the distal tubule and collecting-duct cells in the kidney, allowing for the reabsorption of water and the excretion of concentrated urine. In patients with normal mental status, thirst ensues because of the increased osmolality of the blood, and the increased fluid intake maintains the sodium levels in the high-normal range. However, in the setting of altered mental status, patients may not consume sufficient fluids to maintain normal sodium levels, leading to hypernatremia.

Key learning point: In a patient with recent head trauma and altered mental status, hypernatremia with low urine osmolality is most likely caused by central diabetes insipidus.

C) INCORRECT:

Although post-traumatic dehydration can lead to hypernatremia, this condition causes appropriately high urine osmolality.

D) INCORRECT:

Both cerebral salt wasting and the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion cause hyponatremia; however, neither would manifest with hypernatremia and inappropriately low urine osmolality.

E) INCORRECT:

Although hypothalamic adipsia (absent or impaired thirst) can lead to hypernatremia, this condition causes appropriately high urine osmolality.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for polyuria one day after transsphenoidal pituitary surgery to resect a nonfunctional pituitary adenoma (2 cm in diameter). She has had a urine output of approximately 400 or 500 mL/hour for the past 4 hours and is very thirsty. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and normal visual fields.
Laboratory testing shows a serum sodium level of 147 mEq/liter (reference range, 136–145), a blood glucose level of 105 mg/dL (70–100), and a urine specific gravity of 1.001 (1.001–1.035).
What treatment is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic (3%) saline would not be appropriate treatment for a patient with hypernatremia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are treatments for adrenal insufficiency. Although patients are at risk for central adrenal insufficiency after pituitary surgery, there is usually no indication to give hydrocortisone preemptively; it is given only if the patient is found to have adrenal insufficiency on routine postoperative blood testing. There is no role for fludrocortisone with central adrenal insufficiency; it is used in primary adrenal insufficiency when there is also mineralocorticoid deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline is used for the treatment of patients with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, which is characterized by hyponatremia.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are treatments for adrenal insufficiency. Although patients are at risk for central adrenal insufficiency after pituitary surgery, there is usually no indication to give hydrocortisone preemptively; it is given only if the patient is found to have adrenal insufficiency on routine postoperative blood testing. There is no role for fludrocortisone with central adrenal insufficiency; it is used in primary adrenal insufficiency when there is also mineralocorticoid deficiency.

E) CORRECT:

Patients who undergo transsphenoidal pituitary surgery are at risk for central diabetes insipidus. Surgery can disrupt the hypothalamus, stalk, and posterior pituitary, leading to a block in the release of vasopressin. The symptoms of diabetes insipidus tend to develop within the first 48 hours after surgery.

In diabetes insipidus, the inability to appropriately concentrate urine results in polyuria (urinary excretion >2.5 mL/kg/hour). In addition to polyuria, diabetes insipidus is diagnosed by a combination of symptoms and laboratory findings including dilute urine, polydipsia, dehydration, a high serum sodium level, low urine osmolality, and high serum osmolality.

Patients with diabetes insipidus should be treated with vasopressin. Vasopressin acts on receptors in the kidney to modulate water reabsorption.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient who has low urine osmolality, hypernatremia, and high serum osmolality one day after pituitary surgery is vasopressin.

questions.solution:

Although urinary frequency is a symptom of urinary tract infection (UTI), polyuria with increased urine volume is not. Therefore, although UTI is common in pregnancy, urine Gram stain and culture would not inform the diagnosis of polyuria.

B) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the head can detect structural abnormalities of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis causing reduced ADH, as seen in central diabetes insipidus, but it is not useful for evaluating gestational diabetes insipidus caused by placental vasopressinase production.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has hypernatremia and polyuria. The most appropriate next step is measurement of urine osmolality.

Normally, during pregnancy, the serum sodium level and plasma osmolality are both mildly reduced, and total body water is increased. These changes have been attributed to appropriate release of antidiuretic hormone (also known as vasopressin) in response to the normal vasodilation that occurs during pregnancy, but other hormonal factors may also play a role. Urinary frequency is common during pregnancy, but polyuria (urine excretion >3 liters daily) is uncommon. In addition, the finding of polyuria coincident with hypernatremia raises the concern for diabetes insipidus.

Under normal circumstances, the development of hypernatremia would prompt osmotic stimulation of vasopressin. Vasopressin’s actions on the kidneys lead to reabsorption of water and the formation of concentrated urine. In central diabetes insipidus, there is reduced secretion of vasopressin, and in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, the kidneys are unresponsive to the action of vasopressin.

A normal placenta makes vasopressinase, which metabolizes vasopressin, and this is normally matched by an increase in vasopressin production, so levels are usually normal. In rare cases, excess production of vasopressinase leads to the development of diabetes insipidus in the third trimester. This is more common in women with multiple gestations but can also occur if metabolism of the vasopressinase is hindered by liver dysfunction, as with fatty liver of pregnancy.

Administration of desmopressin acetate, a synthetic vasopressin, can stimulate the vasopressin receptors of the kidneys and result in concentrated urine in the setting of vasopressin deficiency, either from lack of production, as in central diabetes insipidus, or from increased vasopressinase activity, as with the diabetes insipidus of pregnancy; it has no effect in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This agent is not affected by the vasopressinase, and it is safe during pregnancy if it is used cautiously to avoid hyponatremia.

Key learning point: Diabetes insipidus during pregnancy is caused by placental production of vasopressinase and is characterized by polyuria, hypernatremia, and a low urine osmolality.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of thyroid-stimulating hormone is useful in evaluating hyponatremia, because severe hypothyroidism can be associated with hyponatremia. In rare instances, thyrotoxicosis can be associated with polyuria, but there is no evidence of thyrotoxicosis in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria and dilute urine. The serum sodium level will be at the high end of normal or elevated, depending on fluid intake, since hypernatremia stimulates thirst, whereas primary polydipsia is associated with a normal or low serum sodium level. A water deprivation test can differentiate between these two diagnoses, because patients with the latter can concentrate urine after water deprivation. This test is not necessary in patients with hypernatremia and can be dangerous for patients with severe diabetes insipidus because the water losses can be significant.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a complex medical history is evaluated for increasing thirst and urination during the past several months. She reports that she currently drinks up to 4 liters of water each day and usually carries a water bottle with her whenever she leaves the house. She goes to the bathroom every 2 hours during the day and reports passing a large volume of urine each time. She also wakes up once or twice each night to urinate. She reports no dysuria, hematuria, vaginal dryness, or other genitourinary complaints.

She also has a history of type 2 diabetes, which has been managed solely with dietary modification. She has chronic pain, which is thought to be from fibromyalgia and has been complicated by depression. She was started on amitriptyline 100 mg every night 6 months ago. Her other current medications include a multivitamin and acetaminophen as needed.
On physical examination, she is in no acute distress. questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has polyuria, as evidenced by a urine volume >3 liters in 24 hours. Although a report of thirst and increased frequency and volume of urination is suggestive of polyuria, it is preferable to confirm the increased volume with a 24-hour urine collection. Increased frequency of urination without polyuria can occur with a range of genitourinary conditions, such as urinary tract infections and, in men, prostatic disease.

Once polyuria has been confirmed, the main diagnostic possibilities include osmotic diuresis, primary polydipsia, and central or nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI).

Primary polydipsia is the more likely diagnosis in this case and may be related to xerostomia from the patient’s amitriptyline use. Primary polydipsia is associated with a primary increase in water intake (related to dry mouth, a desire to drink more for purported health effects, or psychiatric disease). Because of the increased water intake, the serum sodium level and plasma osmolality are at the lower end of normal or, sometimes, frankly low. In response to the low plasma osmolality, there is reduced or absent release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) by the posterior pituitary, resulting in a dilute urine (with a low urine osmolality).

Key learning point: Polyuria from primary polydipsia is associated with hyponatremia, reduced plasma osmolality, and reduced urine osmolality.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion have evidence of increased ADH levels. Although these patients may have hyponatremia and a low plasma osmolality related to inappropriate retention of water, they usually have relatively low urine volume rather than polyuria, and the urine osmolality is inappropriately high.

C) INCORRECT:

In DI, the primary problem is a reduction in release of ADH from the pituitary gland (central DI) or a diminished effect of ADH on the kidneys (nephrogenic DI). In both types of DI, the reduced effect of ADH leads to a reduced ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine. As a result, a dilute urine with low urine osmolality is generated, leading to a loss of water from circulation. The serum becomes more concentrated, manifesting as a rise in the serum sodium level and plasma osmolality. The increased osmolality promotes the sensation of thirst, leading to polydipsia — usually without the development of frank hypernatremia or hyperosmolality, as long as the patient has an intact thirst mechanism and access to water. In a patient who has DI without access to water, frank dehydration and severe hypernatremia can occur quickly. Although central DI is a reasonable diagnosis to consider in this patient, given her history of pituitary surgery, her low serum sodium level and low plasma osmolality make this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, the risk of central DI is fairly low after transsphenoidal adenomectomy; in one study, the loss of ADH occurred in only about 5% of patients followed for 8 years. Furthermore, when postoperative DI does occur, it occurs early, but this patient’s surgery was 10 years ago. In more challenging cases, additional testing, such as a water deprivation test, may be required. A more recently described test, hypertonic saline infusion with copeptin measurement, is not yet the standard of care.

D) INCORRECT:

In this patient, a urinary tract infection is unlikely because she has true polyuria, she denies dysuria, and her urinalysis does not show evidence of infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Osmotic diuresis may occur in patients with uncontrolled type 2 diabetes; the glucose in the renal tubule exerts an osmotic effect, leading to an increase in the amount of water excreted by the kidneys and, then, polyuria. However, this patient has well-controlled type 2 diabetes according to her glycated hemoglobin finding, and her urinalysis shows no evidence of glycosuria. In addition, the urine osmolality is low, which makes an osmotic diuresis unlikely.

A) INCORRECT:

In primary (or psychogenic) polydipsia, which is associated with excessive water intake, often in patients with psychiatric illnesses, the serum sodium level is typically at the low range of normal or below normal. This patient has acute onset of symptoms (which is less typical of primary polydipsia), has been exposed to cisplatin (a medication with a known side effect of nephrogenic DI), and has no other history to suggest primary polydipsia.

B) INCORRECT:

Although diabetes mellitus can also cause polydipsia and polyuria, this diagnosis is ruled out by the patient's normal serum glucose level and the lack of glycosuria and urinary ketones.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's recent history of polydipsia, polyuria, and nocturia in the setting of cisplatin use is suggestive of acquired nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI).

Normally, antidiuretic hormone (ADH) stimulates the insertion of aquaporins into the apical membrane of the collecting ducts, which makes the collecting ducts permeable to water so that water can be reabsorbed along the concentrating gradient created by the concentrated medulla.

Patients with nephrogenic DI, whether congenital or acquired, cannot respond normally to ADH and cannot form concentrated urine. Their thirst is normal, so if the patient has access to water, they will drink sufficient fluid to keep the serum sodium level within the normal range or at the upper limit of normal. Individuals with DI typically rise during the night to urinate and to drink more fluids. This patient's serum sodium level and serum osmolality are slightly above normal because she is able to increase her free water intake to maintain her electrolytes in this normal range. In DI, the urinary sodium level is typically low because it is excreted in a large volume of dilute urine.

If a water deprivation test is done, patients with DI will have persistently dilute urine with a low urine osmolality despite a rise in the serum sodium level. Patients with nephrogenic DI will not respond to administration of vasopressin. Those with central DI will respond to vasopressin, and the urine osmolality will rise as the urine becomes more concentrated.

Cisplatin is nephrotoxic and can cause nephrogenic DI, as can lithium, foscarnet, and amphotericin B among other medications. If the medication exposure is relatively short in duration, the effect will typically resolve slowly over time. Patients with long-term exposure to these medications may have longer-lasting DI, even once the medication is removed.

Key learning point: Laboratory findings in acquired nephrogenic diabetes insipidus show low urine osmolality and a low urine sodium level in the setting of hypernatremia.

D) INCORRECT:

Ingestion of an alcohol such as methanol, ethanol, or propylene glycol can lead to a hyperosmolar state, but there would be an osmolal gap, which is not present here. In addition, these ingestions do not typically cause polyuria and polydipsia.

E) INCORRECT:

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) typically leads to hyponatremia and low serum osmolality, and the urine osmolality would be high, not low.

A) INCORRECT:

Although diabetes mellitus can also cause polydipsia and polyuria, this diagnosis is ruled out by the patient’s normal serum glucose level and lack of glycosuria or ketonuria. Therefore, pancreatic antibody testing to assess for type 1 diabetes would not be appropriate for this patient.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s new-onset polyuria, polydipsia, nocturia, and unintentional weight loss are suggestive of diabetes insipidus (DI), a relatively rare disorder characterized by an inability to concentrate urine because of either deficiency of antidiuretic hormone (ADH; central DI) or ADH resistance (nephrogenic DI). People with DI have extreme thirst and often prefer cold water to other beverages and food. The combination of polyuria >2 liters/m2 /day, serum osmolality >300 mOsm/kg, and urine osmolality <300 mOsm/kg is diagnostic of DI.

Although this patient’s history is suggestive of DI, the serum osmolality is not high enough to make the diagnosis. Therefore, a provocative test (the water deprivation test) is indicated, to prove that the patient’s urine remains dilute even when the serum osmolality is elevated.

Water deprivation testing is the gold standard for diagnosing DI and helps to distinguish between central and nephrogenic DI. This test is performed in a closely monitored medical setting after an overnight fast. Serum electrolyte levels and serum and urine osmolality are monitored closely, and when serum osmolality rises to >300 mOsm/kg in the setting of dilute urine (urine osmolality <300 mOsm/kg), the diagnosis of DI is made, and subcutaneous vasopressin (synthetic ADH) is administered.

• If the urine output falls and urine osmolality rises in response to vasopressin administration, central DI is diagnosed.
• If the patient does not respond to vasopressin, then nephrogenic DI is diagnosed.

Previously, nearly half of all cases of pediatric central DI were thought to be idiopathic; however, the results of a 2014 study suggest that close surveillance and long-term follow-up reveal an underlying diagnosis in most cases. Possible causes of central DI include genetic disorders; trauma; infiltrative or neoplastic diseases; autoimmune conditions; infectious diseases; and postsurgical, anatomic, or pituitary defects.

Key learning point: When a patient’s history is suggestive of diabetes insipidus, but the serum osmolality is not high enough to make the diagnosis, the most appropriate next step is a water deprivation test.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-week history of fatigue and excessive thirst. During this period, she has not been able to sleep through the night because of the frequent urge to urinate. She also urinates more than usual during the day. She drinks 4–5 liters of water daily. She has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, hypertension treated with lisinopril, and bipolar disorder. Therapy with valproic acid was begun after a manic episode 3 months ago. Serum studies show mild hypernatremia, a high serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. The urine osmolality does not change after 3 hours despite no fluid intake or after administration of desmopressin. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Water restriction is a technique used to treat psychogenic polydipsia (PP). Patients with PP typically have mild hyponatremia and low serum osmolarity. This patient has already had a 3-hour water restriction without any change in her urine osmolarity, making another management option more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks epithelial sodium channels. This medication is used for the treatment of lithium-induced nephrogenic DI. However, this patient is taking valproic acid as a mood stabilizer, which does not lead to nephrogenic DI. In some other cases of nephrogenic DI, potassium-sparing diuretics may be considered but only in addition to first-line therapy and not as a monotherapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Small amounts of 3% saline can increase sodium levels in patients with severe hyponatremia caused by beer potomania. However, this patient has hypernatremia and her history does not suggest beer potomania.

D) CORRECT:

In addition to a low-salt and low-protein diet, hydrochlorothiazide treats nephrogenic DI by paradoxically reducing the volume of urine produced. Hydrochlorothiazide leads to increased sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubules. As a result, less water reaches the ADH-sensitive distal tubules and urine volume decreases.

Key learning point: Hydrochlorothiazide is the first-line treatment for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, as it paradoxically reduces urine output by increasing proximal tubular reabsorption of sodium and water.

E) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin therapy is an effective treatment for central DI. However, this patient has the nephrogenic form of the disease, which does not respond to desmopressin. Moreover, this patient has already been administered desmopressin with no improvement.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of renal disease presents with polyuria, nocturia, polydipsia, mild hypernatremia, a high serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. In combination with the absent response to fluid restriction and desmopressin administration, these features suggest nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI).

One hour after an antidiuretic hormone (ADH) analog injection, her plasma osmolality is 280 mOsmol/kg H2O, and her urine osmolality is 430 mOsmol/kg H2O.
