questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tolvaptan causes selective water excretion in the urine by antagonizing the action of ADH on the vasopressin 2 receptor. It is used to treat hyponatremic states (e.g., caused by syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion). This patient is already excreting excess water in the urine, as her inability to concentrate urine prior to receiving the ADH analog demonstrates.

B) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline can be used to treat syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). This drug inhibits the action of ADH, which in turn leads to dilution of the urine. This patient's laboratory results show high serum osmolarity, which rules out a diagnosis of SIADH. Increased ADH secretion leads to increased water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules and the collecting ducts of the kidneys, resulting in low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluid restriction was already performed with this patient for diagnostic purposes. An inability to concentrate urine after the water deprivation test confirms diabetes insipidus. Moreover, after administration of the ADH analog, urine osmolarity increased, which indicates ADH deficiency. Fluid restriction is the treatment of choice for asymptomatic patients with SIADH and is used in the management of primary polydipsia along with behavioral and pharmacologic therapy. In this patient who lacks sufficient ADH, however, fluid restriction is not an appropriate treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Desmopressin, a synthetic substitute of ADH, is the most appropriate treatment for patients with central diabetes insipidus. In this condition, hypothalamic synthesis or secretion of ADH from the posterior pituitary is deficient. Desmopressin acts by increasing water reabsorption in the renal collecting ducts, thereby decreasing urine output and increasing urine osmolality; it has no effect on the vascular wall and does not cause vasoconstriction.

Primary central diabetes insipidus is most commonly idiopathic. Secondary central is more common and is usually secondary to brain tumors, neurosurgery, head trauma, or infiltrative disease (e.g., sarcoidosis).

E) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) is used to treat nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI). In nephrogenic DI, dysfunction of the ADH receptors in the distal tubule and collecting ducts prevents ADH from exerting its normal function. Treatment with HCTZ leads to a depletion of sodium and hypovolemia, which results in an increase in sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubules. As a result, less water reaches the ADH-sensitive collecting ducts and the volume of urine decreases. HCTZ can also be used as an additive treatment for central DI as its effect is independent of ADH. However, this patient's response to the ADH analog rules out a diagnosis of nephrogenic DI.
questions.hint: This patient has mild hypernatremia, low urine osmolality, and high plasma osmolality. Administration of an ADH analog increases urine osmolality and causes plasma osmolality to normalize. This combination of findings is highly suggestive of central diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for polyuria one day after transsphenoidal pituitary surgery to resect a nonfunctional pituitary adenoma (2 cm in diameter). She has had an increased urine output for the past 4 hours and is very thirsty. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and normal visual fields. Laboratory testing shows an increased serum sodium and an increased blood glucose level. What treatment is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic (3%) saline would not be appropriate treatment for a patient with hypernatremia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are treatments for adrenal insufficiency. Although patients are at risk for central adrenal insufficiency after pituitary surgery, there is usually no indication to give hydrocortisone preemptively; it is given only if the patient is found to have adrenal insufficiency on routine postoperative blood testing. There is no role for fludrocortisone with central adrenal insufficiency; it is used in primary adrenal insufficiency when there is also mineralocorticoid deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline is used for the treatment of patients with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, which is characterized by hyponatremia.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are treatments for adrenal insufficiency. Although patients are at risk for central adrenal insufficiency after pituitary surgery, there is usually no indication to give hydrocortisone preemptively; it is given only if the patient is found to have adrenal insufficiency on routine postoperative blood testing. There is no role for fludrocortisone with central adrenal insufficiency; it is used in primary adrenal insufficiency when there is also mineralocorticoid deficiency.

E) CORRECT:

Patients who undergo transsphenoidal pituitary surgery are at risk for central diabetes insipidus. Surgery can disrupt the hypothalamus, stalk, and posterior pituitary, leading to a block in the release of vasopressin. The symptoms of diabetes insipidus tend to develop within the first 48 hours after surgery. In diabetes insipidus, the inability to appropriately concentrate urine results in polyuria (urinary excretion >2.5 mL/kg/hour). In addition to polyuria, diabetes insipidus is diagnosed by a combination of symptoms and laboratory findings including dilute urine, polydipsia, dehydration, a high serum sodium level, low urine osmolality, and high serum osmolality. Patients with diabetes insipidus should be treated with vasopressin. Vasopressin acts on receptors in the kidney to modulate water reabsorption.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient who has low urine osmolality, hypernatremia, and high serum osmolality one day after pituitary surgery is vasopressin.

A) INCORRECT:

Psychogenic polydipsia causes polyuria and dilute urine, but it is associated with a serum sodium level on the low end of normal or even hyponatremia, whereas the serum sodium in this patient is at the upper limit of normal.

B) INCORRECT:

The syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion is associated with hyponatremia and small volume of inappropriately concentrated urine.

C) INCORRECT:

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's random glucose level is higher than normal at 150 mg/dL, it does not confirm a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes. Confirmation requires a random plasma glucose concentration ≥200 mg/dL in the presence of symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with bipolar I disorder and hypertension comes to the office because of a 2-week history of increased thirst, urinary frequency, and sleep disturbance. He says that he now drinks up to 30 cups of water daily. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Examination shows decreased skin turgor. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?

The elevated serum sodium and osmolality in this patient are inconsistent with this condition. Additionally, the acute onset of symptoms post-surgery and low urine osmolality suggest an inability to concentrate urine, not a dilutional process.

The normal serum glucose level and absence of solute load further exclude osmotic diuresis as a cause.

questions.text: You are evaluating a 35-year-old woman for polyuria one day after she underwent transsphenoidal pituitary surgery to resect a 2-cm nonfunctional pituitary adenoma. She reports increased urine output over the past 4 hours and significant thirst. On examination, she has dry mucous membranes and normal visual fields. Laboratory testing shows elevated serum sodium and elevated blood glucose. Which one of the following treatments is indicated for this patient?

A) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic (3%) saline would not be appropriate treatment for a patient with hypernatremia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are treatments for adrenal insufficiency. Although patients are at risk for central adrenal insufficiency after pituitary surgery, there is usually no indication to give hydrocortisone preemptively; it is given only if the patient is found to have adrenal insufficiency on routine postoperative blood testing. There is no role for fludrocortisone with central adrenal insufficiency; it is used in primary adrenal insufficiency when there is also mineralocorticoid deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are treatments for adrenal insufficiency. Although patients are at risk for central adrenal insufficiency after pituitary surgery, there is usually no indication to give hydrocortisone preemptively; it is given only if the patient is found to have adrenal insufficiency on routine postoperative blood testing. There is no role for fludrocortisone with central adrenal insufficiency; it is used in primary adrenal insufficiency when there is also mineralocorticoid deficiency.

D) CORRECT:

The symptoms of diabetes insipidus tend to develop within the first 48 hours after surgery. In diabetes insipidus, the inability to appropriately concentrate urine results in polyuria (urinary excretion > 2.5 mL/kg/hour). In addition to polyuria, diabetes insipidus is diagnosed by a combination of symptoms and laboratory findings including dilute urine, polydipsia, dehydration, a high serum sodium level, low urine osmolality, and high serum osmolality. Patients with diabetes insipidus should be treated with vasopressin. Vasopressin acts on receptors in the kidney to modulate water reabsorption.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient who has low urine osmolality, hypernatremia, and high serum osmolality one day after pituitary surgery is vasopressin.

E) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline is used for the treatment of patients with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, which is characterized by hyponatremia.
questions.hint: Patients who undergo transsphenoidal pituitary surgery are at risk for central diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after briefly falling asleep at the wheel and veering off the road. She was uninjured. She reports several weeks of persistent thirst and frequent urination, waking multiple times nightly to drink water and void. Since delivering a child by emergency cesarean section 2 months ago, complicated by postpartum hemorrhage requiring transfusion, she has felt fatigued and has had difficulty breastfeeding. Vital signs are BP, 94/58 mm Hg; P, 108; R, 18; T, 36.6°C (97.9°F). She appears mildly dehydrated with dry mucous membranes. Laboratory studies show: sodium 152 mEq/L, potassium 4.1 mEq/L, chloride 110 mEq/L, bicarbonate 25 mEq/L, glucose 94 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL, creatinine 0.8 mg/dL. Urine specific gravity is 1.002. Which of the following underlying processes best explains her current symptoms?

choices.text: Persistent excess arginine vasopressin secretion leading to water retention
Adrenal insufficiency causing salt and water loss with compensatory thirst
Excessive renal glucose excretion from postpartum insulin resistance
Primary psychogenic polydipsia causing water intoxication
Deficient arginine vasopressin secretion due to ischemic pituitary injury

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excess AVP secretion, as in SIADH, causes low urine output and water retention with hyponatremia. This patient’s marked thirst, nocturia, and dehydration indicate water loss rather than retention.

B) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency from anterior pituitary damage can cause fatigue and hypotension but is associated with hyponatremia and low urine output. This patient’s dominant feature—polyuria with nocturnal thirst—points to posterior pituitary (AVP) deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Osmotic diuresis from diabetes mellitus can cause polyuria and thirst, but this typically occurs in the setting of hyperglycemia. Her postpartum history of hemorrhagic shock and endocrine symptoms favors pituitary ischemia rather than metabolic disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary polydipsia leads to overhydration and hyponatremia, not dehydration. Patients typically have low or normal sodium levels.

E) CORRECT:

Correct — This woman’s postpartum hemorrhage and subsequent fatigue, lactation failure, and nocturnal polyuria suggest Sheehan syndrome with posterior pituitary involvement causing central diabetes insipidus. Ischemic injury to the hypothalamic–neurohypophyseal axis leads to AVP deficiency, producing large volumes of dilute urine, dehydration, and compensatory polydipsia that disrupts sleep and daily functioning.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with progressive fatigue, intense thirst, and frequent urination for three weeks. She reports drinking large amounts of water (7–8 liters a day), including waking several times nightly to drink. Her medical history includes pulmonary sarcoidosis treated intermittently with corticosteroids. Vital signs are BP, 92/54 mm Hg; P, 112; R, 18; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and poor skin turgor. Laboratory results are: sodium 158 mEq/L, potassium 4.0 mEq/L, chloride 112 mEq/L, bicarbonate 25 mEq/L, blood urea nitrogen 19 mg/dL, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL, glucose 98 mg/dL, and serum osmolality 310 mOsm/kg. Urinalysis shows specific gravity 1.002 and urine osmolality 70 mOsm/kg. Which of the following is the most appropriate intravenous fluid management strategy?

choices.text: Restrict free water and monitor electrolytes
Administer balanced isotonic crystalloid such as lactated Ringer’s at maintenance rate and monitor electrolytes
Give hypotonic fluids with frequent electrolyte monitoring
Infuse 5% dextrose in normal saline at a maintenance rate for 12–24 hours before reassessing sodium and urine output
Administer isotonic saline to correct intravascular depletion first, then transition to hypotonic fluids once urine output decreases

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluid restriction is contraindicated. In diabetes insipidus, limiting free water will exacerbate dehydration and hypernatremia before hormonal therapy can be titrated.

B) INCORRECT:

Balanced crystalloids like lactated Ringer’s are useful for isotonic dehydration but contain sodium concentrations near physiologic plasma levels. In hypernatremic dehydration, they do not provide sufficient free water to lower serum sodium and can perpetuate the hyperosmolar state. Hypotonic fluids are required for controlled correction.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — The findings indicate hypernatremic dehydration from free-water loss, most consistent with central diabetes insipidus secondary to sarcoid involvement of the hypothalamus or posterior pituitary. The emergency goal is cautious correction of serum sodium using hypotonic solutions that provide free water (5% dextrose in water or 0.45% saline). Sodium should decrease no more than 10–12 mEq/L per 24 hours to avoid cerebral edema. Continuous monitoring of electrolytes and urine output is essential. Once stabilized, the endocrinology team will initiate desmopressin for definitive control of the water diuresis.

D) INCORRECT:

This plan sounds balanced because 5% dextrose in normal saline provides both glucose and isotonic volume support, but it is too hypertonic for treating hypernatremic dehydration due to free-water loss. The normal-saline component supplies excess sodium, limiting the fall in plasma sodium concentration and potentially worsening hypernatremia.

E) INCORRECT:

This plan appears reasonable because isotonic saline is often used for volume resuscitation before switching to hypotonic fluids. However, in central diabetes insipidus, the predominant issue is a free-water deficit rather than true extracellular volume loss. Isotonic saline supplies both sodium and water in equal proportion, which fails to lower serum sodium and may worsen hypernatremia if given beyond the initial stabilization phase. Management should begin directly with hypotonic fluid replacement while initiating desmopressin to curb ongoing water loss.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a 50-pack-year smoking history presents with a 2-month history of profound fatigue, excessive thirst, and frequent urination. He reports an unintentional 15-lb weight loss over the same period. His only medication is lisinopril for hypertension. On examination, his blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg and his pulse is 105/min. Mucous membranes are dry. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 146 mEq/L, serum osmolality of 305 mOsm/kg, and a urine osmolality of 150 mOsm/kg. Serum glucose is 98 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone is a known paraneoplastic syndrome associated with lung cancer. However, it is characterized by excessive ADH action, leading to free water retention. This results in hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and inappropriately concentrated urine, which is the opposite of this patient's laboratory findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Central diabetes insipidus (DI), which is caused by deficient ADH secretion, would manifest with the same laboratory findings of hypernatremia, high serum osmolality, and low urine osmolality. However, a paraneoplastic cause is more likely because this patient's profound smoking history and weight loss suggest malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary polydipsia involves excessive water intake, which can cause polyuria. However, this condition leads to the excretion of a large volume of dilute urine to compensate for the fluid overload, resulting in a low serum osmolality and hyponatremia or low-normal serum sodium. This patient has a high serum osmolality and hypernatremia.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of polyuria, polydipsia, and dehydration, combined with laboratory findings of hypernatremia, high serum osmolality, and inappropriately dilute urine (low urine osmolality), is characteristic of diabetes insipidus (DI). The significant smoking history and constitutional symptoms (weight loss, fatigue) raise strong suspicion for an underlying malignancy, such as lung cancer. Squamous cell lung cancer can cause a paraneoplastic syndrome of hypercalcemia, which is a common cause of acquired nephrogenic DI. Hypercalcemia impairs the kidney's response to ADH at the collecting duct, leading to an inability to concentrate urine.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus is a common cause of polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss. However, the mechanism is an osmotic diuresis caused by hyperglycemia. This patient's serum glucose level is normal, which rules out this diagnosis as the cause of his symptoms.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is in the intensive care unit three days after a severe traumatic brain injury (TBI) from a motorcycle collision. Over the past 8 hours, his urine output has increased to 350 mL/hour. He is intubated and sedated. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), his heart rate is 115/min, and his blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 158 mEq/L and a serum osmolality of 320 mOsm/kg. A urinalysis shows a specific gravity of 1.003 and a urine osmolality of 150 mOsm/kg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) can also occur after TBI. However, SIADH is characterized by excessive ADH secretion, which leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and concentrated urine (high urine osmolality). This patient's laboratory findings of hypernatremia, high serum osmolality, and dilute urine are the opposite of what is seen in SIADH.

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral salt wasting (CSW) is a condition of renal sodium loss following intracranial disease, which leads to volume depletion and hyponatremia. Although it can manifest with polyuria, it is fundamentally a state of salt loss, not free water loss. This patient's primary laboratory abnormality is hypernatremia, not hyponatremia, making CSW unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Osmotic diuresis, which can be caused by substances like mannitol (often used in TBI) or glucose, can cause polyuria and hypernatremia. However, the presence of an osmotic agent in the urine leads to a high urine osmolality and high specific gravity. This patient's urine is dilute, with a very low specific gravity and osmolality, which rules out an osmotic cause for the diuresis.

D) CORRECT:

Central diabetes insipidus is a potential complication of TBI due to damage to the hypothalamus or posterior pituitary, leading to decreased secretion of ADH. The lack of ADH prevents the kidneys from reabsorbing free water in the collecting ducts. This results in the excretion of large volumes of inappropriately dilute urine (polyuria with low urine osmolality and specific gravity) despite rising serum osmolality and hypernatremia. The significant free water loss leads to hypovolemia, evidenced by tachycardia and borderline hypotension. Treatment involves fluid resuscitation and administration of desmopressin, a synthetic analog of ADH.

E) INCORRECT:

Although patients in the intensive care unit can have significant insensible losses that lead to dehydration and hypernatremia, the compensatory physiologic response is ADH release. This response results in the production of a small volume of highly concentrated urine (high specific gravity and osmolality) to conserve water. This patient is producing a large volume of dilute urine, which indicates a failure of this compensatory mechanism.
questions.hint: This patient is producing a large volume of dilute urine despite having a high serum sodium and osmolality.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of bipolar disorder presents with a 3-week history of excessive thirst and frequent urination. He reports drinking over 6 L of water daily but still feels constantly dehydrated. His only medication is lithium carbonate. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium of 152 mEq/L, serum osmolality of 315 mOsm/kg, and urine osmolality of 150 mOsm/kg. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This action impairs the kidney's ability to generate a concentrated medullary interstitium, which is essential for water reabsorption. Using furosemide would worsen the polyuria and free water loss, thereby exacerbating the patient's hypernatremia and dehydration.

B) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin is a synthetic analog of ADH and is the primary treatment for central diabetes insipidus, in which there is insufficient ADH production. This patient's condition is nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, meaning the kidneys are resistant to the effects of ADH. Therefore, administering exogenous ADH in the form of desmopressin would be ineffective because the renal tubules cannot respond to it.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the patient is dehydrated, 0.9% saline is an isotonic fluid with a sodium concentration of 154 mEq/L. This patient's primary deficit is free water, not sodium. Administering isotonic saline would not correct the free water deficit and could worsen the hypernatremia. The appropriate intravenous fluid for correcting hypernatremia is a hypotonic solution, such as 5% dextrose in water.

D) CORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, is a first-line treatment. Its mechanism is paradoxical: by inhibiting the Na-Cl cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule, it induces mild volume depletion. This triggers a compensatory increase in sodium and water reabsorption in the proximal tubule. Consequently, less fluid is delivered to the ADH-resistant collecting ducts, leading to a decrease in urine output and an improvement in hypernatremia. Other management includes attempting to discontinue lithium if clinically feasible and ensuring adequate free water intake.

Amiloride, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can also be used, as it blocks lithium entry into collecting duct cells.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluid restriction is the cornerstone of treatment for the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, which causes hyponatremia. This patient has diabetes insipidus with hypernatremia due to massive renal free water loss. Restricting fluids would be dangerous, as it would prevent him from compensating for his urinary losses, leading to severe, life-threatening hypernatremia and hypovolemia.
questions.hint: This patient has lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, characterized by renal resistance to antidiuretic hormone (ADH).

An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to excessive thirst and frequent urination for the past year. His mother states that her brother had similar symptoms since childhood. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and normal mental status. Administration of intranasal desmopressin results in minimal change in urine output (see lab results).

Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Excessive release of antidiuretic hormone by the hypothalamus
Autoimmune destruction of posterior pituitary cells
Loss-of-function mutation in the vasopressin V₂ receptor gene
Loss-of-function mutation in the Na⁺K⁺2Cl⁻ cotransporter of the thick ascending limb

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive ADH release, as in syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), causes water retention, concentrated urine, and hyponatremia. The patient's polyuria, hypernatremia, and minimal response to desmopressin are inconsistent with SIADH, indicating impaired renal response to ADH.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune destruction of posterior pituitary cells leads to central diabetes insipidus, characterized by impaired ADH production. Desmopressin administration typically reduces urine output in this condition. The minimal change in urine output after desmopressin administration in this patient suggests nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, where the kidneys are unresponsive to ADH.

C) CORRECT:

The boy's symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, and hypernatremia, along with minimal response to desmopressin, suggest nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition arises from a loss-of-function mutation in the vasopressin V₂ receptor gene, impairing the kidney's response to antidiuretic hormone (ADH). This defect prevents aquaporin-2 channels from inserting into the collecting duct cells, leading to an inability to concentrate urine. The familial occurrence of similar symptoms supports an inherited mutation affecting the V₂ receptor.

Key learning point: Diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria, polydipsia, and dehydration due to the inability to concentrate urine, and can have a familial pattern, particularly in X-linked nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

D) INCORRECT:

A mutation in the Na⁺K⁺2Cl⁻ cotransporter, as seen in Bartter syndrome type 1, leads to salt wasting, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, not hypernatremia. The patient's hypernatremia and minimal response to desmopressin indicate a defect in renal response to ADH, not a transporter dysfunction.

questions.text: Two days after undergoing an emergency laparotomy following a motor vehicle collision, a 37-year-old man has increased thirst. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. A review of his chart shows his urine output to be in excess of his fluid intake. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 151 mEq/L and urine osmolality of 110 mOsmol/kg H2O. One hour after the administration of desmopressin, the serum sodium concentration is 147 mEq/L and urine osmolality is 400 mOsmol/kg H2O. One week later, his laboratory values are within normal limits. This patient's condition was most likely caused by damage to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is produced in the hypothalamus (supraoptic nucleus and paraventricular nucleus). This hormone is then stored in, and subsequently released by, the posterior pituitary gland. Ischemia or direct damage (e.g., major surgery or head trauma) to the pituitary gland can affect ADH secretion and cause transient central DI. Features of central DI include polyuria, polydipsia, and increased serum osmolality in the presence of low urine osmolality. In the majority of cases, patients recover the ability to maintain serum osmolality, and ADH secretion is restored.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

B) INCORRECT:

The adrenal cortex produces glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids. Acute adrenal insufficiency can occur in the postoperative period (Addisonian crisis) because of ischemic adrenal damage. Furthermore, acute adrenal insufficiency can be transient, as seen here. However, adrenal insufficiency typically manifests with hypotension and hyponatremia, and this condition would be diagnosed with an ACTH stimulation test, not with desmopressin administration.

C) INCORRECT:

Damage to the proximal renal tubule can manifest with polyuria, which is seen in this patient. However, the polyuric phase typically follows an acute anuric phase, which is not described here. Furthermore, damage to the proximal tubule is not associated with a reversal of the changes in serum and urine osmolality after desmopressin administration.

D) INCORRECT:

Damage to the collecting duct can cause nephrogenic DI. This condition manifests with thirst, polyuria, and hypernatremia as seen in this patient. However, because nephrogenic DI is not responsive to desmopressin, its administration would not result in a reversal of the changes in serum and urine osmolality.

E) INCORRECT:

The supraoptic nucleus produces ADH. Damage to this nucleus leads to central DI, which can manifest with thirst, polyuria, and hypernatremia as seen in this patient. However, because the majority of ADH is produced in the supraoptic nucleus, damage to this structure typically leads to permanent DI, not a quick recovery (transient DI) like the one seen here.
questions.hint: The features of increased thirst, polyuria, and hypernatremia suggest diabetes insipidus (DI). The change in urine osmolality after desmopressin administration can be used to identify the cause of DI.
